title: NISTeHandbook
text: NISTeHandbook R package seeks implement methods NIST/SEMATECH e-Handbook Statistical Methods. current version 4 methods implemented: 4-plot 6-plot Tietjen-Moore Test outliers Probability Plot Correlation Coefficient Plot

title: NISTeHandbook
text: 4-plot 6-plot similar EDA methods testing assumptions given data. Let us start 4 plot, using example eNist website. use LEW dataset, describes study physical behaviour steel-concrete beams periodic load. response variable deflection center point, 200 observations collected. first load RPackage: package provides data set directly. use 4-plot function simply provide observations function:  function outputs 4plot object contains every plot ggplot object, can modify individual plot. Printing 4plot object gives plot shown . number bins set default 11, can specify bin sizes 4plot function.
code: library(NISTeHandbook) library(ggplot2) head(LEW.DAT) #>   Deflection #> 1       -213 #> 2       -564 #> 3        -35 #> 4        -15 #> 5        141 #> 6        115 fourplots <- fourPlot(LEW.DAT$Deflection) fourplots fourplots <- fourPlot(LEW.DAT$Deflection, bins = 20)

title: NISTeHandbook
text: use specific modify plots can access 4plot object. Let us take sequence plot.  wish modify plots can use ggplot2: finding specific geoms fourplot, see documentation ?fourplots. can modify save change 4plot.  assumptions conclusions plots consult handbook.
code: fourplots$seq_plot fourplots$seq_plot + geom_line(color="red") fourplots$seq_plot <- fourplots$seq_plot + geom_line(color="red") fourplots

title: NISTeHandbook
text: 6-plot behaves similar way 4-plot. function attempts linear Y versus X fit. Let us load data handbook website, another fashion: looking response variable, beam deflections, V1 various different loads V2. create six plot input response explanatory variable.  sixPlot returns sixPlot object contains 6 ggplots, can manipulated similar manner 4plot.
code: PONTIUS <- read.table("https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/datasets/PONTIUS.DAT", skip=25) head(PONTIUS) #>        V1     V2 #> 1 0.11019 150000 #> 2 0.21956 300000 #> 3 0.32949 450000 #> 4 0.43899 600000 #> 5 0.54803 750000 #> 6 0.65694 900000 sixPlot(PONTIUS$V2, PONTIUS$V1)

title: NISTeHandbook
text: Imagine approximately normal distributed data, want check outliers. Tietjen-Moore test suited . can use TMTest test exactly \(k\) outliers, , less. Let us take data handbook (Tietjen Moore also used original paper): x-values observations vertical semi-diameters planet Venus… EDA, suspect might two outliers.  TMTest function shows normal QQ plot, remind us test valid approximately normal distributed data. also see two suspected outliers. print shows us can conclude suspected outliers indeed outliers.
code: x = c(-1.40, -0.44, -0.30, -0.24, -0.22, -0.13, -0.05, 0.06, 0.10, 0.18, 0.20, 0.39, 0.48, 0.63, 1.01) tmTest(x,2) #>  #> Results of  Tietjen Moore Test  #> -------------------------- #> H_0:   there are no outliers in the data  #> H_a:   the  2  most extreme points are outliers  #>  #> Test statistic:  E_k =  0.2919994  #> Significance level:  a =  0.05   #> Critical value for lower tail:   0.3133549   #> Critical region: Reject H_0 if E_k <  0.3133549

title: NISTeHandbook
text: teacher told find appropriate distribution data, might come across PPCC page Engineering Statistics handbook. mentions can use Tukey-Lambda PPCC plot symmetric distributions. PPCC plot graphical technique identifying good value shape parameter distribution. Tukey-Lambda distribution shape parameter \(\lambda\) used indicate several common distributions. \(\lambda=-1\) : distribution approximately Cauchy \(\lambda=0\) : distribution exactly logistic \(\lambda=0.14\) : distribution approximately normal \(\lambda=0.5\) : distribution U-shaped \(\lambda=1:\) distribution exactly uniform idea distribution fit data, can use Tukey-Lambda PPCC plot. Let us generate normal data: now imagine know data generated. can use PPCC_tukey  observe distribution symmetric, normal probability plot suggests normal. really normal? Let us ask Tukey:  get Tukey-Lambda PPCC plot, showing correlation coefficient different values \(\lambda\). print shows highest correlation 0.999 \(\lambda = 0.14\). also conveniently tell us data indeed normal.
code: set.seed(123) data <- rnorm(500) fourPlot(data) tukeyPPCC(data) #> Maximum value of the correlation coefficient = 0.999 #> Lambda                                       = 0.14 #> The distribution of your data might be aprroximately normal

title: NISTeHandbook
text: completing Tukey-lambda PPCC plot, can follow another PPCC plot check best-fit. Let show example. Let’s load weibull data, forget weibull. Let us EDA, 4plot.  see fairly symmetrical histogram, might approximate normal distributed. Let us try confirm tukeyPPCC.  Interesting. output tells us data might come uniform beta something short-tailed. PPCC function can fit data either gamma weibull distribution. data fits gamma shape parameter 10, best. .. correlation coefficient .999 weibull shape parameter 2.23. data fact generated weibull shape parameter 2.
code: weib_data = RANDWEIB.DAT head(weib_data) #>           Y #> 1 0.8052801 #> 2 0.7403102 #> 3 1.0452200 #> 4 0.7830150 #> 5 1.2402800 #> 6 1.0057760 fourPlot(weib_data$Y) tukeyPPCC(weib_data$Y) #> Maximum value of the correlation coefficient = 0.992 #> Lambda                                       = 0.24 #> The distribution of your data might be short-tailed (U-shaped), for example beta or uniform PPCC(weib_data$Y, 'gamma') #> Maximum value of the correlation coefficient = 0.998 #> Optimal value of the shape parameter         = 10 PPCC(weib_data$Y, 'weibull') #> Maximum value of the correlation coefficient = 0.999 #> Optimal value of the shape parameter         = 2.23

title: Authors and Citation
text: Tony Hin. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Hin T (2021). NISTeHandbook: Implements Statistical Methods NIST Handbook. R package version 0.0.1.
code: @Manual{,   title = {NISTeHandbook: Implements Statistical Methods from the NIST Handbook},   author = {Tony Hin},   year = {2021},   note = {R package version 0.0.1}, }

what: Implements Statistical Methods from the NIST Handbook
title: Implements Statistical Methods from the NIST Handbook
text: R Package implement methods NIST/SEMATECH e-Handbook Statistical Methods. Given user package data, package implement use following methods: 4-plot EDA techniques testing underlying assumptions https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section2/eda23.htm Probability Plot Correlation Coefficient Plot: graphical technique identifying shape parameter distributional family best describes data set. https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/ppccplot.htm Tietjen-Moore Test Outliers Tietjen-Moore test used detect multiple outliers univariate data set follows approximately normal distribution. https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda35h2.htm 6 plot Collection 6 specific graphical techniques whose purpose assess validity Y versus X fit https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/6plot.htm Project manager: Laura Horsfall Folmer Documentation manager: Laura Horsfall Folmer Quality manager: Tony Lung Ca Hin
code: - run sequence plot - lag plot - histogram  - normal probability plot. - generate a PPCC plot - a normal probability plot should be generated along with a htest object. - Scatter plot of the response and predicted values versus the independent variable - Scatter plot of the residuals versus the independent variable - Scatter plot of the residuals versus the predicted values - Lag plot of the residuals - Histogram of the residuals - Normal probability plot of the residuals.

title: PPCC Plot — PPCC
text: Firstly, data tukey_PPCC-function find appropriate distribution data. PPCC plot used first find good value shape parameter, lastly probability plot (example, use function ProbPlot) generated find estimates location scale parameters addition provide graphical assessment adequacy distributional fit. can use data either weibull gamma distribution, far.

title: PPCC Plot — PPCC
code: data <- RANDWEIB.DAT$Y PPCC(data, "weibull") #> Maximum value of the correlation coefficient = 0.999 #> Optimal value of the shape parameter         = 2.23

title: Four Plot — fourPlot
text: 4-plot EDA technique testing underlying assumptions. returns list 4 plots; sequence plot, lag plot, histogram normal probability plot.

title: Four Plot — fourPlot
code: fourPlot(data, bins=11)

title: Four Plot — fourPlot
text: data list data values. bins Number bins show histogram.

title: Four Plot — fourPlot
text: frame 4 plots.

title: Four Plot — fourPlot
text: 4-plot outputs frame four plots. run sequence plot answer questions whether data fixed location /fixed variation. lag plot show whether data random. histogram test data follows normal distribution. normal probability plot tests together histogram, data follows normal distribution. plots made ggplot2 can elaborated needed. seq_plot uses geom_line() lag_plot uses geom_point() hist_plot uses geom_histogram() quant_plot uses geom_qq() See vignette details .

title: Four Plot — fourPlot
code: x <- LEW.DAT$Deflection fourPlot(x)

title: Six Plot — sixPlot
text: 6-plot collection 6 specific graphical techniques whose purpose assess validity Y versus X fit. returns list 6 plots; Scatter plot (predicted vs independent variable) Scatter plot (residuals vs independent variable) Scatter plot (residuals vs predicted values) Lag plot residuals Histogram residuals Normal probability plot residuals

title: Six Plot — sixPlot
code: sixPlot(X, Y, bins=30)

title: Six Plot — sixPlot
text: X list X values. Y list Y values. bins Number bins show histogram.

title: Six Plot — sixPlot
text: frame 6 plots.

title: Six Plot — sixPlot
code: X <- 1:100 Y <- rnorm(100, x * 10, 50) #> Error in rnorm(100, x * 10, 50): object 'x' not found sixPlot(X, Y) #> Error in eval(predvars, data, env): object 'Y' not found

text: Tietjen-Moore test function test k outliers tails.

text: data list univariate data. k number suspected outliers.

title: Tietjen-Moore Test for Outliers — tmTest
text: object shows result hypothesis.

title: Tietjen-Moore Test for Outliers — tmTest
text: Tietjen-Moore test used detect multiple outliers univariate data set follows approximately normal distribution. testing single outlier, Tietjen-Moore test equivalent Grubbs' test.

text: function returns Tukey Lambda PPCC plot, maximum value correlation coefficient together corresponding lambda value indication kind distribution data might fallow.

title: Tukey-Lambda PPCC Plot — tukeyPPCC
text: function useful symmetric distributions. can indicate type distribution data follows, example data long-tailed short-tailed, based lambda value, can indicate several common distributions. Tukey-Lambda PPCC plot used suggest appropriate distribution follow PPCC probability plots appropriate alternatives.

title: Tukey-Lambda PPCC Plot — tukeyPPCC
code: data <- rnorm(100) tukeyPPCC(data) #> Maximum value of the correlation coefficient = 0.997 #> Lambda                                       = 0.08 #> The distribution of your data might be long-tailed, for example double exponential or logistic

title: NA
text: functions take data input.
code: - 4Plot: A function that outputs four plots that tests EDA assumptions. Made by Laura. - PPCC: A function that finds the best fit member within a distribution family and shows how good the best fit is. Made by Laura. - TMTest: A function that tests whether the data contains k outliers. It uses hypotehsis testing. Made by Tony. - 6Plot: A function that outputs six plots to asses the validity of a Y vs. X fit. Made by Tony.

title: NA
code: - htest class for TMTest - ggplot
